reviewText:
A fun strategy/management game that can keep you occupied for minutes or hours.

You are a babysitter to dwarfs. You use arrows, walls and dynamite to guide them towards treasures and away from danger. The dangers that await the dwarfs are lava, water and nasty creatures like goblins and spiders. And the dwarfs love looking for treasure, so much so that they will dig into a lava pit to find some. Fortunately you are given the tools to prevent this from hapening. You get guide arrows to switch their direction, dynamite to create holes for water and lava to flow in and walls to block the flow of water and slow the flow of lava. You can also seal up areas permanently by hardening rock, but this can cost a lot of gold (especially in the harder difficulties).

With the game's multiple mode, difficulty and time settings you can enjoy a nice long high score game, or go for a quick 5 minute hardcore challenge. There is also an alternate game, akin to a carnival shooting gallery (throwing axes/shooting at side scrolling targets), which can be fun for a bit.

For the achievement & perfect game collectors, this game offers a 2 for 1. Any achievement you get in the paid version will also be unlocked if you play the free version. The achievements themselves are fairly easy to get within a few hours. The only issue is that some of the achievements will not register in the paid version, unless you unlock them in the free version (you can meet the criteria in the paid version and not need to buy the dlc).

Overall a nice game, 7/10. Definitely worth picking up in a sale.
I wouldn't buy it out of sale (£7.99 / $9.99), but it may be worth it to some, so try the free version first.

reviewText:
Ok so the only reason I ever played this game to start with was to get an item in Killing Floor lol. But as it just so happens to be, this isn't a bad little game. It's simple enough in design but can yield a nice challenge.

Between the lava rushes and floods, mother nature can be one hateful ♥♥♥♥♥ in this game. You may think having only two environmental hazards would quickly become stale, but I didn't find that to be the case. They can be unforgiving.

There are several modes in Dwarfs?! but for the most part your goal is to mine as much of the map as you can, without your base being overcome before the time runs out.

In each game you'll have ups and downs contained within caves of unknown content until entrance that could either hold Gold, a Boss, mini-hoard, lava, or water.

You can spend in game currency to use blocks that block off cave systems and prevent your workers from breaching the containment area but be warned, if you block off the entire system without first discovering it's contents there will be a penalty in the form of a deduction from your gold... an important item I may add. One tactic you may want to try is blocking off all but 1 square then send in 2 workers with dynamite equipped in case it's lava or water. In that event it's best to sacrifice a worker to make a drainage hole in the earth and completely sealing that hazard, which will give you a bonus.

Along the way you may construct outposts with your gold and train warriors and workers. Good thing they put this in because the map is rather large and this will cut down on travel time during combat or intervention.

In the harder modes controlling your workers becomes extremely important. There are more hazards to be found and they flow faster so having 2 or 3 workers tap into separate conduits will be a quick death for you.

So that's the general idea, I'll let you explore the rest of the game for yourself :)

Oh yeah, don't forget about the Killing Floor award, whatever it was. Happy gaming!

reviewText:
This is repetitive but really fun. It's a casual 2D strategy Indie game which includes a bonus Tower Defense game-mode, and more. This game is more of a game where you run in the background whilst doing other things in the non-virtual world. For example: I love to paint my Games Workshop miniatures, so I play this game in the background, listening to calm, enjoyable music while i'm painting my miniatures. If my Dwarfs need help or require micro-managing so they won't release Doom, I pause my painting and micro-manage them. When it's all safe, I return to painting.

The main game-play or game-mode is the, 'Arcade mode'. This is where you select a difficulty a time limit, so a random generated underworld spawns. Your Dwarfs will go mining anywhere they like, although you can set them paths to mine for a bit of gold. Caves will spawn in the map which can contain good or bad things or nothing for your Dwarfs. It could be an empty cave, it could filled with water of lava that will spread killing anything in it's path until contained or until it reaches and destroys your town. It could be filled with goblins, or even a boss goblin; 'Shaman'. It could be filled with treasure or with rich minerals to mine. Minerals will spawn around the map to be mined so it can be turned into gold.

The 'Campaign' are basically challenges as well as a tutorial.

The 'Skirmish' are basically bonus game-modes. The first one is 'Sandbox'. This is basically where you can play around with the underworld. Spawn in everything you like and mess around with the settings of things like: water or lava speed. You can make the world for your dwarfs to thrive, or just die. It's basically arcade mode but instead of a random generated world, you get to create the world before or during when your dwarfs mine, with no time limit.

Rush mode is basically Arcade mode but with one difficulty and no time limit. The catch is however, new Dwarfs spawn all the time and you have 200 lives (so if 200 dwarfs die, you die/loose).

Dark mode is like Arcade mode but there is only one difficulty and no time limit. However the catch is, everything that isn't mined is hidden. So you don't know where the minerals are or the caves.

Endless mode is basically Arcade mode but you decide how big the map is as well as there is no-time limit.

Carnival game mode is basically a bonus game mode. You are a dwarf and you have throw axes at moving targets. You can move within a small area but you only have 10 axes. This game-mode is fun to compete with friends to see who can get the highest score.

The last game-mode is called 'Base defence.' This basically tower defence but with a twist. You get to create your own paths with digger Dwarfs. Whenever a portal spawns, just before the goblins spawn, a digger dwarfs spawns. He'll try to dig to your village the quickest way possible, but you can always create him your own paths, for some money. Whenever you kill a goblin, you get money. And like any other tower defence game, you can buy towers and then upgrade them.

Overall I think this game is great and fun to play. It's worth getting this game if you like casual games.

reviewText:
A fun, cute, casual game.  At its core this game is like a very basic version of pacman meets minecraft.  Dwarfs spawn continously and move about the mine map on their own.  You guide them and coax them to do your bidding to explore, gain money/increase score.  As more dwarfs spawn the harder it is to control them.

There are no complicated elements to distract you from the main aim of the game which is to guide your dwarfs as they mine the map uncovering resources or caves with rewards or dangers.  You can build outposts with guards to fight off monsters, use dynamite to cut-off dangerous traps or turn earth to concetre to block of sections you dont want your miners to explore.  These simple mechanics mean you can get into the game very, very quickly.  However just because it is simple to play does not mean it is easy to master...

The game has a lot of depth with several game modes including a set of campaign challenges which plays like a tutorial that gets harder and encourages you to develop your technique.  These will become vital in the Arcade mode or the Skirmish challenges.  Gameplay remains the same throughout with the difficultly and the achievements being the driver for you to take on harder and harder challenges.

Overall I found this fun if the last few challenges a little frustrating but, its great to start up if you just want some quick frantic fun for an hour or so.  It is repetitive with only the randomly drawn maps changing from game to game.  Though for what it costs its value for money.  Just dont expect AAA graphics.

reviewText:
This top down casual strategy game seems pretty crude at first. And it is. There isn't much to it. The UI and unit control is clunky and difficult to work with. It's a bit buggy and it's not much to look at. However... it's pretty addictive.

The poor UI seems to be part of the difficulty of the game. When you are trying to cope with a river of Lava consuming your tunnel network, two Giant Spider Queens infesting your mine with hundreds of spiders, a flood, and all the while trying to mine gold to fund your efforts, things get pretty frantic and desperate.

You may find it very annoying in fact, as often the game will give you virtually no time to react. There is a slow time ability on a long cooldown, but even with this often it is impossible to stop a lava flow in time for example.

You have no direct control over the dwarves. Instead you can choose to spend money to force them to walk and dig in a particular direction. This makes every decision difficult if you are trying to conserve money, which you will need for military units, and for blocking off fatal sections of the mine, or forcing your miners to commit suicide to block off a tunnel.

The gameplay kind of reminds me of Dungeon Keeper (i'm sure there are better examples though) and makes me wonder if this game doesn't have a better approach to unit control. After all, you wouldn't expect to be able to rapidly redeploy your forces and execute manoeuvres underground.

There are a few random mini games thrown in, a few different play modes, even a tower defence for some reason. But the main game is where it's at. Try it on Normal mode for an hour and see if you can last that long! Definitely worth a look if you are interested in strat or managment games.

reviewText:
Damn dwarves, always digging too deep… Uh… Erm-ahem. Hi.

If you’re reading this, chances are you’re interested in Dwarfs!?. Maybe you think it could be your kind of game. I have to start by saying that if you’re looking for something remotely like Dwarf Fortress, this is not it. Dwarfs!? is a completely unrelated casual game.

With that out of the way, what is Dwarfs!?, really? Well, it’s a game about managing dwarves as they dig further and further from their home. If it doesn’t sound too hard, believe me, this job has a lot more excitement than you think.

As the dwarves dig deeper, you’ll want to direct them towards minerals and treasure caves, which boost your score. However, they may also find monsters, water veins, or worse, streams of lava. On that event, you have to try and seal that path before the whole level is flooded and/or your main base is destroyed. This requires an escalating amount of micromanagement, but hey, just try to not die.

And… that’s basically it, really. It comes with several modes, each of which has few different rules, but I’ll admit I spent most of my time with the default, arcade mode, which gives you a time limit (5, 15, 30 or 60 minutes) to explore the cave as far as you can and maximize your score. I could have stuck with the F2P version for that, but I don’t regret my purchase. It’s a pretty good casual game that I find myself coming back to every once in a while.

…it could have done without the obnoxious voice acting, though.

What a fan-tas-tic game ! I didn't expect something good, since it looked 'just' alright and I didn't exactly know what to expect. But it's the best €4,50 I've spent so far during this 2011 summer sale. Allow me to explain what you have to do in this game. Even though it's a score-based game, I'm having lots of fun with the digging and managing. And it's always random. It's awesome !
It's similar to a lot of other sandbox games, since you have no real objectives. You just have to survive for xx minutes and try to do as much as you can. I LOVE IT !

reviewText:
For a basic idea of a 2D game, Dwarfs!? has done the best! You have certain game modes to choose from: challenges, survival or campaign. Make your units dig until they are drowned, burn to death, killed by enemies or blown up by their own explosives.

I enjoyed playing survival more than any other mode. Survival has great gameplay, at least until you don't die by digging into fire or dangerous liquids. By digging, you will gain coins and veins such as gold veins will give you a ton more gold, explore caves for treasure or discover enemies to fight.

Campaign is really nice, along with the tutorial on how to play. The challenging part is when striking water or fire, they spread and can ruin the game by making you lose everything. Once the fire or water reaches your main base, it is over!

The more you dig and the more money you're receiving, build more bases, hire more diggers to help. This is a really enjoyable game and I'd recommend it to anyone.

After playing the tutorial and one session on normal I have to say that this game is rather fun and unfun at the same time.

The major problem is the lacking overview. When you go for an 60 minute session the dungeon/mine becomes confusingly big rather quick. Somewhere I trained some dwarfs and in some other locations I build more diggers (both for an expense in income). Number 3: When an outpost becomes destroyed we cannot rebuild it? The warrior dwarfs always are confused and so am I. Do I need to build a new outpost from scratch for the full prize?

I think these small Quality-of-Life fixes would greatly improve the experience since they give the player more control.

reviewText:
Lemmings meets tunnels and dwarves.

Dwarfs!? is top down 2d strategy game developed by Tripwire Interactive. You play as an overseer whose goal is to manage the dwarve's mining operations and make sure things go smoothly.

As an overseer you have to control the safety of your mine through moving units, dealing with environmental hazards and building new structures. Gold is the main currency in the game. It is obtained by simply letting miners detroy blocks on the map. Miners will go off on their own detroying blocks and earning gold and aren't all directly controlled by the player. However, the direction the dwaf is moving in can be manipulated by selecting them and draging  (which creates a path) in a direction to make them move somewhere else. This can't be done sparringly however as it costs gold and the further the direction you send the dwarf, the more it costs. That is why it is best to let the dwarves do their own thing and simply resolve problems when they arise (like lemmings). There are also traps such as water and lava (which floods the mine). When they reach your town hall, the game ends. To deal with this, you have to block the entrance with walls. Lava will break down walls over time, so you have to set explosives to create holes for lava to fall into. Further hazards are enemies such as goblins, spiders, skeletons etc which can be found within the mines. To help deal with these foes you can recruit soldiers. All units gain experience as they complete their tasks, which makes them perform better when they level up. Besides building walls and dynamite, you can also build outposts. Outposts can be used to train your soldiers which increase health and damage. Training takes time and the more time it takes, the more gold it costs.

There are plenty of game modes to play. Campaign involves completing challenges which range between getting a certain score, number of units or defeating foes with limited troops. There is also a tower defence mode, where you have to defend your town hall against waves of foes through clever tunnel and tower placement. Arcade mode has you explore a massive map in timed game, trying to get the highest score. Skirmish includes a variety of different modes including a carnival game (where you have to hit the targets) and endless mode (play a 60 minute game). With all theses game modes available, there is plenty of replayability.

Audio is decent. The music is alright and gives a somewhat light-hearted medieval feel. Voice acting from the tutorial guy is decent as well.

Graphics are dated. Textures don't have alot of detail to them and the models are basic.

If you enjoy games where you can sit back and let your workers do most of the work, and solve issues when they occur, as well as having plenty of game modes, this game is for you.
